Here are the names of my relatives who were murdered in Busk. @McMinnCountySch, Please ask yourself if erasing their collective memory truly reflects the values of the community you serve. https://t.co/E0wxCCo6vI

@McMinnCountySch, I encourage you to go back to the book that you just banned, look each mouse in the eye, and remember that they aren't just characters. They each represent the six million Jews who were murdered in the Holocaust, and they each had names.
I only know their names because a handful of survivors wrote them down to publish a remembrance - a yizkor book - in their memory.
My immediate family was fortunate, because my great-grandfather, Max Karawan, migrated to the US in the early 1900s. Most of his extended family wasn't so lucky.
All that came to an end on May 21, 1943, when the Nazis massacred the town's 1,500 remaining Jews, including all of my relatives who didn't manage to get out beforehand.
@McMinnCountySch Not very long ago, there was a community in a town called Busk. It's a small village in western Ukraine that once had a thriving Jewish community dating back hundreds of years.
